Award.AwardTitle: Lagrangian Flow Boundaries, Transport, and Vortex Cores in Pre-genesis Disturbances
Award.AbstractNarration:
This research builds on the "marsupial paradigm" to examine which pre-genesis disturbances eventually become tropical storms and hurricanes. A favorable environment most typically exists within African Easterly Wave (AEW) critical layer flows as an essential precursor environment for the dynamics (wind) and thermodynamics (heat and moisture) to support development. Though a protected kinematic environment is necessary for development, typically less than 20% of these waves actually produce hurricanes. Classic methods to evaluate the near storm environment use an Eulerian framework in which the storm is studied as it flows through a fixed domain. The proposed research seeks to study these flows through the use of Lagrangian Coherent Structure (LCS) analysis in which the diagnostic tools follow the air flowing into the developing pre-storm environment. Influx of moisture, dry air and vorticity (spin in the atmosphere) across closed streamlines of the steady flow disrupt the dynamics that support development in an otherwise protected environment.

Intellectual Merit
The use of Lagrangian Coherent Structures in diagnosing the pre-genesis storm environment may lead to:
(1) An improved understanding of the lateral flow-following transport and exchange of air masses interior and exterior to the wave pouch
(2) An improved description of transitions from tropical depression to tropical storm including diagnosis of the kinematic protection due to the shear-sheltering of the vortex core
(3) Extending the kinematic analysis to study vertical alignment of Lagrangian boundaries and consequences of alignment or misalignment for cyclogenesis (storm spin-up)
(4) Addressing predictability of cyclogenesis by applying these methods to ensemble forecasts

Broader Impacts
A more complete understanding of the role of flow-following (Lagrangian) boundaries and vortex cores may aid in improved forecasting of storm spin-up with greater lead-time and lower false alarm rates.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The frozen-in-time or Eulerian view of the structure of tropical disturbances prior to tropical cyclone formation can be misleading, as the apparent boundaries between a storm and its environment are highly dependent on the speed at which a storm is moving.  This research has investigated a moving-frame, or Lagrangian, approach that locates the coherent structures that protect a developing storm from its environment in a way that is independent of the frame of reference of the observer.  These coherent structures are divided into three classes, starting at the outer region of the storm on the scale of 200 km where manifold boundaries in the mid-troposphere separate an aggregate of rotating cloud systems from hostile dry air so that they can intensify.  A set of closed manifolds were shown to be a universal characteristic of developing storms systems while non-developing systems often exhibit open manifold boundaries allowing dry air to penetrate the storm and quench convection.  The possible configurations of closed manifolds have been identified in a series of case studies of Hurricanes Sandy (2012), Nate (2011), Edouard (2014), and Nadine (2012), which each developed from different types of large-scale precursors.  These closed boundaries contrasted with the open manifold boundaries of Tropical Storm Gaston (2010), which dissipated and did not re-develop.   

 

Once tropical cyclones have sufficiently intensified, two additional types of coherent structures appear interior to the manifolds; a vortex core that is identified as a region of persistent strain-free rotation, and a shear sheath of high strain that surrounds and protects the vortex core.  Each of these coherent structures can be easily identified in a scalar field of a quantity called the Lagrangian Okubo-Weiss parameter, which is essentially an average along the path of air parcels of the difference between the amount of rotation and amount of stretching.  Positive values indicate favorable regions for cyclone development while negative values occur in hostile regions.   In a historical study of global model analyses, we identified enhanced Lagrangian Okubo-Weiss values for every developed storm system, and a shear sheath present near the time of transition to tropical storm status.  These characteristics are indeed universal; they are present independent of the large-scale weather pattern from which a tropical cyclone originates, or in which ocean basin the tropical cyclone develops. 

 

The mathematical properties of this quantity allow it to be used for automated identification of pre-genesis disturbances, by identifying maximal regions that are nearly circular with little filamentation.  A continuing outcome of this research is a near-real-time automated tracking of pre-genesis disturbances in all ocean basins that will provide continued guidance to researchers and forecasters about the Lagrangian structure of potential developing systems. 

 

The location of these structures was an interdisciplinary accomplishment using dynamical systems theory from applied mathematics, and the methods that we have devised have broader applicability to many other fluid flows.  In addition to the applications that we have used at the tropical cyclone system scale, these methods are applicable at a variety of other scales, and will lead to a deeper understanding of processes that occur at smaller scales within the Lagrangian boundaries, and for other meteorological applications such as in the development of mid-latitude weather systems.
